rdf:Description.rdfs:label: model
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A description of a model used or produced by the work described in the publication.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: supplementary information description
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Information describing supplementary information relating to the document, including references or links to the relevant supplementary information.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: discussion
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: An interpretation and discussion of the results obtained and an analysis of their significance, in support of conclusions. These conclusions may be part of this discussion or may be included in a separate section of the document.

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Silvio Peroni
rdf:Description.dc:title: The Discourse Elements Ontology (DEO)
rdf:Description.dc:description: DEO, The Discourse Elements Ontology, is an ontology written in OWL 2 DL that provides a structured vocabulary for rhetorical elements within documents (e.g. Introduction, Discussion, Acknowledgements, Reference List, Figures, Appendix), enabling these to be described in RDF. It uses some of the rhetorical block elements from the SALT Rhetorical Ontology and the Ontology of Rhetorical Blocks.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: David Shotton
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: The Discourse Elements Ontology is an ontology for describing the major rhetorical elements of a document such as a journal article. It is a subsidiary ontology that is imported into the Document Components Ontology, itself part of SPAR, the Semantic Publishing and Referencing Ontologies. Other SPAR ontologies are described at http://purl.org/spar/.
rdf:Description.dc:rights: This work is distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution License (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/).

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: results
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: The report of the specific findings of an investigation, given without discussion or conclusion being drawn.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: motivation
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A description of the justification for undertaking the work described in the publication.
An element of a document that carries out a rhetorical function.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: discourse element
caption
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Text accompanying another item, such as a picture.

A description in a research paper documenting the specialized methods used in the work described. This description is often combined with a description of the materials used, in a section entitled 'Methods and Materials', 'Experimental' or a related term.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: methods

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A proposal for new investigation to be undertaken in order to continue and advance the work described in the publication.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: future work

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A related resource that is included either physically or logically in the described resource.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: has part

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: An initial description which states the purpose and goals of the following writing, and, in the case of journal articles, typically includes background information on the research topic and a review of related work in the area.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: introduction
materials
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A description in a research paper documenting the specialized materials used in the work described. This description is often combined with a description of the methods used, in a section entitled 'Methods and Materials', 'Experimental' or a related term.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: acknowledgements
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Usually part of the preface, or a separate section in its own right, often as part of the back matter, it acknowledges those, including funding agencies, who contributed to the undertaking of a research project described in a publication, or to the creation of the work in some way. In scientific articles, the acknowledgements are usually placed as a separated section immediately following the Discussion or Conclusions.
A description of the part that this publication plays in the overall field.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: contribution
evaluation
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A consideration of the value, meaning and significance of the results obtained.

Presentation of information that is essential for understanding the situation or problem that is the subject of the publication. In a journal article, the background is usually part of the Introduction, but may be present as separated section.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: background

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Text in which the author names the person or people for whom he/she has written the document, or to whose memory it is dedicated.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: dedication
epilogue
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A piece of writing at the end of a work of literature or drama, usually used to bring closure to the work.

The authors' critical review of current knowledge by specific reference to others' work, both in terms of substantive findings and theoretical and methodological contributions to a particular topic. This description is often included within the introduction section.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: related work

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Information describing a person and his or her life history and contributions.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: biography

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A related resource.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: has relation
author contribution
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A description of the roles played by an author in the publication.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: dataset description
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Information describing a dataset held in an external database or repository and including a reference to it, such as a database ID or an accession number.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: prologue
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A piece of writing at the beginning of a work of literature or drama, usually used to set the scene or to introduce the work.

A reflection on the preceding text, summarizing the evidence, arguments or premises presented in the document and their logical outcomes. Conclusions are a fundamental feature in academic research publications, and may be included in the Discussion section.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: conclusion

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A presentation of a use case or test, based on a real or hypothetical situation, used to help someone think through a complex problem or system.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: scenario

rdf:Description.dc:description: A concise description of the issues that needed to be addressed by a work described in the document.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: problem statement
is part of
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A related resource in which the described resource is physically or logically included.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: bibliographic reference
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A reference, usually contained in a footnote or a bibliographic reference list, that refer to another publication, such as a journal article, a book, a book chapter or a Web site. The inclusion of the bibliographic reference in a publication constitutes the performative act of bibliographic citation.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: postscript
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Text added after the signature of a letter, or sometimes after the main body of an essay or book.

rdf:Description.rdfs:label: data
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A textual description of data used or produced in the work which the document describes, or the data themselves.
Information describing an external resource and including a reference to that resource.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: external resource description

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Informative text that explicitly explains another item, such as a figure or a table.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: legend
reference
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A reference to a specific part of the document, or to another publication.
